column1: Bournemouth  (listen) is a coastal resort town on the south coast of England. At the 2011 census
column2: the town had a population of 183
column4: making it the largest in the administrative county of Dorset. With Poole to the west and Christchurch in the east
column5: Bournemouth is part of the South East Dorset conurbation
column6: which has a population of 465

column1: Before it was founded in 1810 by Lewis Tregonwell
column2: the area was a deserted heathland occasionally visited by fishermen and smugglers. Initially marketed as a health resort
column3: the town received a boost when it appeared in Augustus Granville's 1841 book
column4: The Spas of England. Bournemouth's growth accelerated with the arrival of the railway
column5: and it became a town in 1870. Part of the historic county of Hampshire
column6: Bournemouth joined Dorset for administrative purposes following the reorganisation of local government in 1974. Through local government changes in 1997
column7: the town began to be administered by a unitary authority independent of Dorset County Council
column8: although it remains part of that ceremonial county. Since April 2019 the unitary authority has been merged with that of Poole
column9: as well as the non-metropolitan district of Christchurch to create the Bournemouth
column10: Christchurch and Poole unitary authority.

column1: The town centre has notable Victorian architecture and the 202-foot (62 m) spire of St Peter's Church
column2: one of three Grade I listed churches in the borough
column3: is a local landmark. Bournemouth's location has made it a popular destination for tourists
column4: attracting over five million visitors annually with its beaches and popular nightlife. The town is also a regional centre of business
column5: home of the Bournemouth International Centre or BIC
column6: and a financial sector that is worth more than £1
column7: 000 million in gross value added.

column1: The first mention of Bournemouth comes in the Christchurch cartulary of 1406
column2: where a monk describes how a large fish ("uni magno piscis")
column3: 18 feet (5.5 metres) long
column4: was washed up at "La Bournemothe" in October of that year and taken to the Manor of Wick; six days later
column5: a portion of the fish was collected by a canon from Christchurch Priory and taken away as tithe. "La Bournemowthe"
column6: however
column7: was purely a geographic reference to the uninhabited area around the mouth of the small river which
column8: in turn
column9: drained the heathland between the towns of Poole and Christchurch. The word bourne
column10: meaning a small stream
column12: old English for a brook. From the latter half of the 16th century "Bourne Mouth" seems to be preferred
column13: being recorded as such in surveys and reports of the period
column14: but this appears to have been shortened to "Bourne" after the area had started to develop. A travel guide published in 1831 calls the place "Bourne Cliffe" or "Tregonwell's Bourne" after its founder. The Spas of England
column16: calls it simply "Bourne" as does an 1838 edition of the Hampshire Advertiser. In the late 19th century "Bournemouth" became predominant
column17: although its two-word form appears to have remained in use up until at least the early 20th century
column18: turning up on a 1909 ordnance map.

column1: In the 12th century the region around the mouth of the River Bourne was part of the Hundred of Holdenhurst. The hundred later became the Liberty of Westover when it was extended to include the settlements of North Ashley
column2: Muscliff
column3: Muccleshell
column4: Throop
column5: Iford
column6: Pokesdown
column7: Tuckton and Wick
column8: and incorporated into the Manor of Christchurch. Although the Dorset and Hampshire region surrounding it had been the site of human settlement for thousands of years
column9: Westover was largely a remote and barren heathland before 1800. In 1574 the Earl of Southampton noted that the area was "Devoid of all habitation"
column10: and as late as 1795 the Duke of Rutland recorded that "... on this barren and uncultivated heath there was not a human to direct us".In the late 19th and early 20th centuries the Borough of Bournemouth would grow to encompass a number of ancient settlements along the River Stour
column11: including Longham where a skull thought to be 5
column12: 500 years old was found in 1932. Bronze Age burials near Moordown
column13: and the discovery of Iron Age pottery on the East Cliff in 1969
column14: suggest there may have been settlements there during that period. Hengistbury Head
column16: was the site of a much older Palaeolithic encampment. During the latter half of the 16th century James Blount
column18: began mining for alum in the area
column19: and at one time part of the heath was used for hunting
column20: although by the late 18th century little evidence of either event remained. No-one lived at the mouth of the Bourne river and the only regular visitors to the area before the 19th century were a few fishermen
column21: turf cutters and gangs of smugglers.

column1: Prior to the Christchurch Inclosures Act 1802
column2: more than 70% of the Westover area was common land. The act
column3: together with the Inclosure Commissioners' Award of 1805
column4: transferred 5
column5: 000 acres (2
column6: 000 ha) into the hands of five private owners
column7: including James Harris
column8: 1st Earl of Malmesbury
column9: and Sir George Ivison Tapps. In 1809 the Tapps Arms public house appeared on the heath. A few years later
column12: retired army officer Lewis Tregonwell and his wife
column13: moved into their new home built on land purchased from Tapps. The area was well known to Tregonwell who
column15: spent much of his time searching the heath and coastline for French invaders and smugglers.Anticipating that people would come to the area to indulge in the newly fashionable pastime of sea-bathing
column16: an activity with perceived health benefits
column17: Tregonwell built a series of villas on his land between 1816 and 1822
column18: which he hoped to let out. The common belief that pine-scented air was good for lung conditions
column20: prompted Tregonwell and Tapps to plant hundreds of pine trees. These early attempts to promote the town as a health resort meant that by the time Tregonwell died in 1832
column21: Bournemouth had grown into a small community with a scattering of houses
column22: villas and cottages. The town would ultimately grow up around the scattered pines and tree-lined walk to the beach
column23: later to become known as the Invalids' Walk.After the death of Tapps in 1835
column24: his son Sir George William Tapps-Gervis inherited his father's estate. He hired the young local architect Benjamin Ferrey to develop the coastal area on the east side of the stream. Bournemouth's first hotel
column25: later to become part of the Royal Bath Hotel
column26: opened in 1838 and is one of the few buildings designed by Ferrey still standing and operating. Bournemouth grew at a faster rate as Tapps-Gervis began developing the area similarly to the south coast resorts of Weymouth and Brighton. Despite enormous investment
column27: the town's share of the market remained modest. In 1841 Tapps-Gervis invited the physician and writer Augustus Granville to stay. Granville was the author of The Spas of England
column28: which described health resorts around the country
column29: and as a result of his visit
column30: he included a chapter on Bournemouth in the second edition of his book. The publication of the book
column31: and the increase in visitors seeking the medicinal use of seawater and the pine-scented air
column32: helped the town to grow and establish itself as an early tourist destination.

column1: In the 1840s Benjamin Ferrey was replaced by Decimus Burton
column2: whose plans for Bournemouth included the construction of a garden alongside the Bourne stream
column3: an idea first mooted by Granville. The fields south of the road crossing (later Bournemouth Square) were drained and laid out with shrubberies and walks. Many of these paths
column4: including the Invalids' Walk
column5: remain in the town today. A second suggestion of Granville's
column6: a sanatorium
column7: was completed in 1855 and greatly raised Bournemouth's profile as a place for recuperation.At a time when the most convenient way to arrive in the town was by sea
column8: a pier was considered to be a necessity. Holdenhurst Parish Council was reluctant to find the money
column9: and an attempt to raise funds privately in 1847 had only succeeded in financing a small 100 feet (30 m) jetty. The Bournemouth Improvement Act of 1856 granted greater financial autonomy to the town and a pier was approved that year. A number of wooden structures were built before an 838 feet (255 m) cast iron design by Eugenius Birch was completed in 1880. Under the Act
column10: a board of 13 Commissioners was established to build and organise the expanding infrastructure of the town
column14: street lighting and street cleaning.The arrival of the railways in 1870 precipitated a massive growth in seaside and summer visitors to the town
column15: especially from the Midlands and London. In 1880 the town had a population of 17
column18: when railway connections to Bournemouth were at their most developed
column19: the town's population had risen to 60
column20: 000 and it had become a favourite location for visiting artists and writers. The town was improved greatly during this period through the efforts of Sir Merton Russell-Cotes
column21: the town's mayor and a local philanthropist
column22: who helped to establish the town's first library and museum. The Russell-Cotes Art Gallery & Museum was housed in his mansion
column24: it was given to the town. Bournemouth became a municipal borough in 1890 and a county borough in 1900.As Bournemouth's growth increased in the early 20th century
column28: and more hotels. Other new buildings included the war memorial in 1921 and the Bournemouth Pavilion
column29: the town's concert hall and grand theatre

column1: The town escaped heavy bombing during the Second World War
column2: but the seafront incurred great damage when it was fortified against invasion. The cast iron lampposts and benches along the front were removed and melted down for munitions
column3: as was much of the superstructure from both Bournemouth and Boscombe piers before they were breached to prevent their use by enemy ships. The large amounts of barbed wire and anti-tank obstacles along the beach
column4: and the mines at the foot of the chines
column5: took two years to remove when peace was finally achieved.

column1: The Royal National Lifeboat Institution stationed an inshore lifeboat at Bournemouth between 1965 and 1972. Coverage for the area has otherwise been provided from Poole Lifeboat Station. The Bournemouth International Centre (BIC)
column2: a large conference and exhibition centre
column3: was constructed near the seafront in 1984
column4: and in the following year Bournemouth became the first town in the United Kingdom to introduce and use CCTV cameras for public street-based surveillance.In 1993
column5: the IRA orchestrated a terrorist attack in the town centre. The only injuries sustained were minor ones but over £1 million in damage was caused.The Waterfront complex
column6: which was intended to hold an IMAX cinema
column7: was constructed on the seafront in 1998. The 19-metre-high (62-foot) concrete and smoked glass building featured a wavy roof design
column8: but was despised by residents and visitors alike because it blocked views of the bay and the Isle of Purbeck. In 2005 it was voted the most hated building in England in a 10
column9: 000-person poll conducted by the Channel 4 programme Demolition
column10: and was pulled down in spring 2013. The site is now used as an outdoor event arena. The council has recently completed a larger redevelopment of the site and adjoining council land.

column1: In 2012 Bournemouth was unsuccessful in its bid for city status
column2: losing out to Chelmsford in competition with 26 other towns to commemorate Queen Elizabeth II's Diamond Jubilee.

column1: Historically Bournemouth was part of Hampshire
column2: with neighbouring Poole
column3: just to the west of the border
column4: in Dorset. At the time of the 1974 local government re-organisation
column5: it was considered desirable that the whole of the Poole/Bournemouth urban area should be part of the same county. Bournemouth
column6: therefore
column7: became part of the non-metropolitan county of Dorset on 1 April 1974. On 1 April 1997
column8: Bournemouth became a unitary authority
column9: independent from Dorset County Council. For local elections the district was divided into 18 wards
column10: with the Bournemouth Borough Council elected every four years. In the 2011 local elections the Conservatives held overall control
column11: winning 45 of the available 51 seats. The Council elects a mayor and deputy mayor annually. The Mayor of Bournemouth for 2019-20 is Councillor Susan Phillips.As from April 2019
column12: the nine councils of Dorset were merged into two and Bournemouth became part of a unitary authority with Christchurch and Poole (known as BCP). For the purposes of the Lieutenancy it remains part of the ceremonial county of Dorset. BCP held its first elections in 2019
column13: which resulted in the Conservatives as the largest party
column14: but with No Overall Control; A Unity Alliance Administration of other groups subsequently formed. The next elections are due to occur in 2024.

column1: Bournemouth is represented by two parliamentary constituencies in the House of Commons; Bournemouth East and Bournemouth West. In the 2017 general election
column2: the former was held for the Conservatives by Tobias Ellwood with 51.9% of the vote
column3: while the latter was also held for the Conservatives by Conor Burns with 53.5%. However
column4: the seats saw some of the largest increases in Labour vote share in the country
column5: with increases of over 18% in each. Tobias Elwood and Connor Burns were both re-elected in 2019 with slightly reduced majorities.

column1: Bournemouth is about 94 miles (151 km) southwest of London. The borough borders the neighbouring boroughs of Poole and Christchurch to the west and east respectively and the East Dorset District to the north. Poole Bay lies to the South. The River Stour forms a natural boundary to the north and east
column2: terminating at Christchurch Harbour; while the River Bourne rises in Poole and flows through the middle of Bournemouth town centre
column3: into the English Channel. The towns of Poole
column4: Bournemouth and Christchurch form the South East Dorset conurbation with a combined population of over 400
column5: 000. Bournemouth is both a retail and commercial centre. Areas within Bournemouth include: Boscombe
column6: Kinson
column7: Southbourne
column8: Springbourne
column9: Throop
column10: Westbourne
column11: Winton and Pokesdown. The area's geology has little variety
column12: comprising almost entirely of Eocene clays which
column14: supported a heathland environment. Patches of the original heath still remain
column17: much of which is designated a Site of Special Scientific Interest. This heathland habitat is home to all six species of native reptile
column18: the Dartford warbler and some important flora such as sundew and bog asphodel. Small populations of Exmoor pony and Shetland cattle help to maintain the area.

column1: Bournemouth is directly north of Old Harry Rocks
column2: the easternmost end of the Jurassic Coast
column3: 96 miles (155 km) of coastline designated a World Heritage Site in 2001. Bournemouth's own coastline stretches from Sandbanks to Christchurch Harbour and comprises mainly sandy beaches backed by gravel and sandy clay cliffs. These cliffs are cut by a number of chines which provide natural access to the shore. At the easternmost point lies Hengistbury Head
column4: a narrow peninsula that forms the southern shore of Christchurch Harbour. It is a local nature reserve and the site of a Bronze Age settlement.

column2: Bournemouth has a temperate oceanic climate with moderate variation in annual and daily temperatures
column3: mild summers
column4: and cool winters. From 1981 to 2010 the annual mean temperature was 10 to 11 °C (50 to 52 °F). The warmest months are July and August
column5: which have an average temperature range of 12 to 22 °C (54 to 72 °F)
column6: while the coolest months are January and February
column7: which have an average temperature range of 1 to 8 °C (34 to 46 °F). Average rainfall in Bournemouth is around 31 inches (800 mm) annually
column8: well below the national average of 44.3 inches (1
column9: 126 mm). It records both higher and lower temperatures than would be expected for its coastal location. Since 1960
column10: temperature extremes as measured at Bournemouth Hurn Airport have ranged from 34.1 °C (93.4 °F) in August 1990
column11: down to −13.4 °C (7.9 °F) in January 1963. The lowest temperature recorded in recent years was −10.4 °C (13.3 °F) in December 2010. The February record high was broken in 2019
column12: with a new record temperature of 17.8C.

column1: Bournemouth lies at the centre of a green belt region that extends into the wider surrounding counties. It is in place to reduce urban sprawl
column2: prevent the towns in the South East Dorset conurbation from further convergence
column3: protect the identity of outlying communities
column4: and preserve nearby countryside. This is achieved by restricting inappropriate development within the designated areas
column5: and imposing stricter conditions on permitted building.Bournemouth has small areas of green belt within its district to the north and east
column6: mostly along the fringes of the shared border with the Christchurch and East Dorset districts. These cover landscape features and greenfield facilities including the River Stour
column7: Stour Valley Way
column8: Millhams Mead and Stour Valley nature reserves and arboretum
column9: Hengistbury Head
column10: and the small communities of Throop and Holdenhurst. Turbary Park is a heathland which is a protected Site of Special Scientific Interest.

column1: Historically Bournemouth has suffered from negative rates of natural increase and has relied on immigration to maintain population growth. In 2007 however
column2: births exceeded deaths for the first time
column3: and this trend has continued through to 2011. This
column4: coupled with a substantial increase in people moving into the area
column5: has led to a sharp rise in the resident population since 2001. Of the total population
column6: 3.3% are 85 or over
column7: compared to 2.2% nationally; however the largest group of people moving into the area are students in the 16-24-year age group
column8: and 9% of the current population are between 20 and 24. In England this age group accounts for only 7%. According to the Centre for Cities in 2016
column9: Bournemouth's population had the third highest average age of any city in the UK
column10: at 42.8 years.

column1: Similarly to the rest of Dorset
column2: Bournemouth's economy is primarily in the service sector
column3: which employed 95% of the workforce in 2010. This was 10% higher than the average employment in the service sector for Great Britain and 11% higher than the South West. Of particular importance are the financial and public service sectors which through 2011 continued to show sustained growth. Compared to the rest of the country
column4: Bournemouth performed well in these two areas but under performed in transport and communications.The smallest geographical region for which Gross Value Added information is available is the NUTS3 area
column5: Bournemouth and Poole. The latest figures

column9: Nationwide Building Society
column10: and the Liverpool Victoria
column12: and RIAS insurance companies. The manufacturing sector is predominantly based in neighbouring Poole

column14: domestic and overseas visitors made more than 5.6 million trips to the town and spent over £460 million between them. The equivalent of 8
column15: 531 full-time jobs exist as a result which accounts for 15% of all employment in the town. Bournemouth seafront is one of the UK's biggest attractions with 4.5 million visitors in 2011. RNLI lifeguards provide seasonal coverage of Bournemouth's beaches.With a third of all town centre businesses in the leisure industry
column16: Bournemouth has a booming nightlife economy and is a popular destination for stag and hen parties. These party-goers contribute £125 million a year to the economy and support 4
column17: 000 jobs. In 2010 the town was awarded a Purple Flag for providing a wide variety of night-time activities while maintaining the safety of both residents and visitors. An independent report published in 2012 indicates there has been a rise in antisocial behaviour which it attributes to the increase in nightlife.Those of working age make up approximately 65% of Bournemouth's population and of these

column19: 400 people in 2011 but not all of these were Bournemouth residents. Of those employed in Bournemouth based industries
column20: 29.32% were employed in the public administration
column21: education and health sector. This compares favourably with Dorset
column23: and the country as a whole
column24: as do the other large sectors; distribution

column1: 37.2% of Bournemouth's resident population are employed full-time while 13.3% are employed part-time. An additional 7.1% full-time workers are self-employed
column2: 3.1% are self-employed part-time. Full-time students with jobs account for 5.3% and 3.8% are unemployed.The shopping streets are mostly pedestrianised with modern shopping malls
column3: Victorian arcades and a large selection of bars
column4: clubs
column5: and cafés. North of the centre there is an out-of-town shopping complex called Castlepoint. The 41-acre (17 ha) site has 40 units and was the largest shopping centre in the UK when it opened it 2003. Other major shopping areas are situated in the districts of Westbourne and Boscombe.

column1: Bournemouth is a tourist and regional centre for leisure
column2: entertainment
column3: culture and recreation. Local author and former mayor
column4: Keith Rawlings
column5: suggests that Bournemouth has a thriving youth culture due to its large university population and many language school students. In recent years
column6: Bournemouth has become a popular nightlife destination with UK visitors and many clubs
column7: bars and restaurants are located within the town centre. In a 2007 survey by First Direct
column8: Bournemouth was found to be the happiest place in the UK
column9: with 82% of people questioned saying they were happy with their lives.Major venues for concerts include BIC
column10: Pavilion Theatre and O2 Academy. Built in 1984
column11: the BIC is also a popular place for party political conferences and has been used by all three major political parties. Its four auditoria make it the largest venue on the south coast. The O2 and Pavilion are older and are both Grade II listed buildings. The O2
column12: which opened in 1895 as the Grand Pavilion Theatre
column13: was initially used as a circus and later for music hall theatre. The Pavilion opened in 1929 as concert hall and tea room while also providing a venue for the municipal orchestra. It continues to provide traditional entertainment today
column15: ballet and operas. Bournemouth has more than 200 listed buildings
column16: mainly from the Victorian and Edwardian eras
column17: including three grade I churches; St Peter's
column18: St Clement's and St Stephen's.The Russell-Cotes Museum is a Grade II* listed
column19: villa completed in 1901. It houses artefacts and paintings collected by the Victorian philanthropist Merton Russell-Cotes and his wife during their extensive travels around the world. The four art galleries display paintings by William Powell Frith
column24: Albert Moore and Dante Gabriel Rossetti. It was Russell-Cotes who successfully campaigned to have a promenade built; it runs continuously along the Bournemouth and Poole shoreline.

column2: Central and Upper Gardens are Grade II* public parks
column3: leading for several miles down the valley of the River Bourne through the centre of the town to the sea. Bournemouth has a further 425 acres (172 ha) of parkland. Initially serving to compensate for the loss of common rights after common land was enclosed in 1802
column4: it was held in trust until 1889 when ownership passed to Bournemouth Corporation and the land became five public parks: King's Park
column5: Queen's Park
column6: Meyrick Park
column7: Seafield Gardens and Redhill Common.The detailed Land Use Survey by the Office for National Statistics in 2005 noted that the local authority area of Bournemouth had the third-highest proportion of land taken up by domestic gardens
column9: of the 326 districts in England; narrowly less than the London Boroughs of Harrow and Sutton at the time with 34.7% and 35.1%.One of Bournemouth's most noted cultural institutions is Bournemouth Symphony Orchestra which was formed in 1893 under Dan Godfrey. It became the first municipal orchestra in the country when in 1896
column10: Bournemouth Borough Council took control and Godfrey was appointed musical director and head of the town's entertainments. Originally playing three concerts a day during the summer season
column11: in the great glass palm house known as the Winter Gardens; the orchestra is now based in Poole and performs around 130 concerts a year across Southern England.Bournemouth is currently host to a number of festivals. Bournemouth Food and Drink Festival is a ten-day event which combines a market with live cookery demonstrations. The Arts by the Sea Festival is a mix of dance
column15: and music which was launched in 2012 by the local university
column17: and is set to become an annual event. The Bourne Free carnival is held in the town each year during the summer. Initially a gay pride festival
column18: it has become a celebration of diversity and inclusion. Since 2008
column19: Bournemouth has held its own air festival over four days in August. This has featured displays from the Red Arrows as well as appearances from the Yakovlevs
column22: Battle of Britain Memorial Flight including Lancaster
column24: Spitfire and also the last flying Vulcan. The festival has also seen appearances from modern aircraft such as the Eurofighter Typhoon. The air festival attracts up to a million people over the four-day event. Bournemouth 7s Festival is a sports and music festival taking place in May each year. Hosting rugby
column28: the event is a celebration of team sports in a festival atmosphere and was launched in 2008.

column1: The town was especially rich in literary associations during the late 19th century and earlier years of the 20th century. P. C. Wren author of Beau Geste
column2: Frederick E. Smith
column3: writer of the 633 Squadron books
column4: and Beatrice Webb
column5: later Potter
column6: all lived in the town. Paul Verlaine taught at Bournemouth a preparatory school and the writer J. R. R. Tolkien
column7: spent 30 years taking holidays in Bournemouth
column8: staying in the same room at the Hotel Miramar. He eventually retired to the area in the 1960s with his wife Edith
column9: where they lived close to Branksome Chine. Tolkien died in September 1973 at his home in Bournemouth but was buried in Oxfordshire. The house was demolished in 2008.Percy Florence Shelley lived at Boscombe Manor; a house he had built for his mother
column10: Mary Shelley
column11: the writer and author of the Gothic horror novel
column12: Frankenstein. Mary died before the house was completed but she was buried in Bournemouth
column13: in accordance with her wishes. The family plot in St Peter's churchyard also contains her parents William Godwin and Mary Wollstonecraft
column14: and the heart of her husband
column15: Percy Bysshe Shelley.Robert Louis Stevenson wrote The Strange Case of Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde and most of his novel Kidnapped from his house "Skerryvore" on the west cliff
column16: Westbourne. A novel of Stevenson's life while residing in Westbourne was written by Adelaide A. Boodle
column17: who had met him there. Henry James
column18: already acquainted with Stevenson through correspondence
column19: and residing in Bournemouth in 1885 in large part because his invalid sister Alice lived there
column20: visited Stevenson most evenings.Vladimir Chertkov established a Tolstoyan publishing house with other Russian exiles at Tuckton
column21: and under the 'Free Age Press' imprint
column22: published the first edition of several works by Leo Tolstoy. Author Bill Bryson worked for a time with the Bournemouth Echo newspaper and wrote about the town in his 1995 work Notes from a Small Island.

column1: Bournemouth has three Grade I listed churches
column2: St Peter's and St Stephen's in the town centre and St Clement's in Boscombe. St Peter's was the town's first church
column3: completed in 1879 and designed by George Edmund Street. In his book
column4: England's Thousand Best Churches
column5: Simon Jenkins describes the chancel as "one of the richest Gothic Revival interiors in England"
column6: while the 202 feet (62 m) spire dominates the surrounding skyline. When the architect
column7: John Loughborough Pearson
column8: designed St Stephen's his aim was to "bring people to their knees". It has a high stone groined roof
column9: twin aisles and a triforium gallery
column10: although the tower lacks a spire.

column1: The borough has two piers: Bournemouth Pier
column2: close to the town centre
column3: and the shorter but architecturally more important Boscombe Pier. Designed by the architect Archibald Smith
column4: Boscombe Pier opened in 1889 as a 600 feet (180 m) structure which was extended to 750 feet (230 m) in 1927 when a new head was constructed. Added in 1958
column5: the boomerang-shaped entrance kiosk and overhanging concrete roof is now a Grade II listed building. In 1961 a theatre was added but this was demolished in 2008 when the rest of the pier was renovated. In 2009
column6: fashion designer Wayne Hemingway described Boscombe Pier as "Britain's coolest pier". It was also voted Pier of the Year 2010 by the National Piers Society.In 1856
column7: Bournemouth Pier was a simple
column8: wooden jetty. This was replaced by a longer
column9: wooden pier five years later
column10: and a cast-iron structure in 1880. Two extensions to the pier in 1894 and 1905
column11: brought the total length to 305 metres (1
column13: the structure was strengthened to allow for the addition of a Pier Theatre
column14: finally constructed in 1960. This survived until the 2000s when it was turned into a climbing adventure centre. Between 1979 and 1981
column16: saw a great deal of reconstruction work
column17: and the addition of a large two-storey
column18: octagonal-shaped entrance building.Built as the Mont Dore Hotel in 1881
column19: Bournemouth Town Hall was designated a Grade II listed building in 2001. Designed by Alfred Bedborough in the French
column21: the foundation stone was laid by King Oscar II of Sweden and Norway and the hotel opened in 1885. The buff brick exterior features Bath stone dressings and terracotta friezes. The main entrance is sited within a projected façade that reaches to the eaves and is topped with a pediment
column22: while above sits a belvedere with turrets and a pavilion roof. During the First World War the hotel was used as a hospital for British and Indian soldiers and after as a convalescent home. It never opened as a hotel again and was purchased by Bournemouth Borough Council in 1919.Built in the Art Deco style in 1929
column24: the Pavilion Theatre was at the time considered to be the greatest ever municipal enterprise for the benefit of entertainment. Built from brick and stone
column25: the frontage features square Corinthian columns. Still a popular venue
column26: it is today a Grade II listed building.The Bournemouth Eye was a helium-filled balloon attached to a steel cable in the town's lower gardens. The spherical balloon was 69 metres (226 feet) in circumference and carried an enclosed
column27: steel gondola. Rising to a height of 150 metres (490 feet)
column28: it provided a panoramic view of the surrounding area for up to 28 passengers.  After the balloon suffered damage in 2016
column30: Lower Central Gardens Trust and S&D Leisure announced in 2017 that the contract for operating the Bournemouth Eye would not be renewed due to "increased operating costs."

column1: The town has a professional football club
column2: AFC Bournemouth
column3: known as the Cherries
column4: which play in the Championship  AFC Bournemouth play at Dean Court near Boscombe in Kings' Park
column5: 2 miles (3 km) east of the town centre.Bournemouth Rugby Club
column6: which competes in the National League Division Two South
column7: has its home at the Bournemouth Sports Club
column8: next to Bournemouth Airport
column9: where it hosts an annual Bournemouth Sevens Festival
column10: a combined Rugby sevens and netball tournament with an associated food
column12: music and entertainment festival. Oakmeadians RFC is the oldest RFU Accredited Rugby Club in Bournemouth
column13: established in 1963.They train and play at Meyrick Park competing in the South West Division. Bournemouth Cricket Club also plays at Bournemouth Sports Club and is reported to be one of the biggest cricket clubs in the country. Its first team plays in the Southern Premier League.Dean Park is a former county cricket ground
column14: once home to Hampshire County Cricket Club and later Dorset County Cricket Club. Today it is a venue for university cricket.The BIC has become a venue for a round of the Premier League Darts Championship organised by the Professional Darts Corporation.The Bournemouth Rowing Club
column15: is the town's coastal rowing club. Established in 1865 as Westover and Bournemouth Rowing Club
column16: it is reported to be the oldest sporting association in the county. The club regularly competes in regattas organised by the Hants and Dorset Amateur Rowing Association which take place on the South Coast of England between May and September.Other watersports popular in Poole Bay include sailing and surfing
column17: and there are a number of local schools for the beginner to learn either sport. Bournemouth has the third largest community of surfers in the UK and in 2009 an artificial surf reef
column18: one of only four in the world
column19: was constructed there. The reef failed to deliver the promised grade 5 wave
column20: suffered a series of delays and ran over budget

column1: The principal route to the town centre is the A338 spur road
column2: a dual carriageway that connects to the A31 close to the Hampshire border. The A31 joins the M27 at Cadnam and from there the M3 to London and the A34 to the Midlands and the North can be accessed. The main road west is the A35 to Honiton in Devon which runs through the South East Dorset Conurbation and continues east as far as Southampton
column3: albeit as a non-primary route. The A350 in the neighbouring borough of Poole provides the only northern route out of the conurbation. National Express coaches serve Bournemouth Travel Interchange & Bournemouth University. There are frequent departures to London Victoria Coach Station and Heathrow and Gatwick Airports. Local buses are provided mainly by two companies
column4: Wilts & Dorset
column5: the former National Bus Company subsidiary and now owned by the Go-Ahead Group
column6: and Yellow Buses
column7: the former Bournemouth Council-owned company and successors to Bournemouth Corporation Transport
column8: which began operating trams in 1902. Other operators serving the town include Damory Coaches and the Shaftesbury & District bus company.

column1: There are two stations in the town
column2: Bournemouth railway station and Pokesdown railway station to the east. Parts of western Bournemouth can also be reached from Branksome station. All three stations lie on the South Western Main Line from Weymouth to London Waterloo. South Western Railway operates a comprehensive service along this line
column3: which also serves Southampton
column4: Winchester and Basingstoke to the east
column5: and Poole
column6: Wareham
column7: and Dorchester South to the west. Before its closure in 1966
column8: Bournemouth was also served by the Somerset and Dorset Joint Railway which provided direct access to Somerset and the Midlands.

column2: Bournemouth Airport was transferred to the Civil Aviation Authority in 1944 and was the UK's only intercontinental airport before the opening of Heathrow Airport in 1946. Acquired by the Manchester Airports Group in 2001
column3: the airport underwent a £45 million phased expansion programme between 2007 and 2011. Situated near the village of Hurn in Christchurch
column4: Dorset
column5: the airport is 7 kilometres (4.3 mi) from Bournemouth town centre and serves around 600
column6: 000 passengers annually. There are direct flights to 23 international destinations in nine countries: Cyprus
column7: Finland
column8: Greece (3 destinations)
column9: Italy (4)
column10: Malta

column1: The Bournemouth local education authority was first set up in 1903 and remained in existence until local government was reorganised in 1974 when Bournemouth lost its County Borough status and became part of the county of Dorset. Under the later reforms of 1997
column2: Bournemouth became a unitary authority and the Bournemouth local education authority was re-established.The local council operates a two-tier comprehensive system whereby pupils attend one of the 26 primary schools in the borough before completing their education at secondary school. Bournemouth is one of the minority of local authorities in England still to maintain selective education
column3: with two grammar schools (one for boys
column4: one for girls) and ten secondary modern/comprehensive schools. There are also a small number of independent schools in the town
column5: and a further education college. Bournemouth has two universities: Bournemouth University and Arts University Bournemouth
column6: both of which are located across the boundary in neighbouring Poole. They are also home to AECC University College (formally known as Anglo European College of Chiropractic)
column7: which is located on Parkwood Road in Bournemouth. In 2012
column8: 60.7% of the borough's school leavers gained 5 GCSEs of grade C or above. This was slightly better than the national average of 59.4% and above the average for the rest of Dorset
column9: with 58.8% of pupils from the local authority of Poole
column10: and 54.1% from the remainder of the county

column1: The 2011 census revealed that 57.1% of the borough's population are Christian. With all other religions combined only totalling 4.7%
column2: Christianity is by far the largest religious group.

column1: 40% of the borough falls within the Church of England Diocese of Salisbury. The remainder
column2: to the east
column3: belongs to the Diocese of Winchester.

column1: The Roman Catholic Diocese of Portsmouth incorporates most of Bournemouth with the exception of two small parishes to the west which are covered by the Diocese of Plymouth.The borough has several notable examples of Victorian church architecture including the previously mentioned St. Peter's
column2: the churchyard of which contains the grave of the author Mary Shelley; St Stephen's Church
column3: completed in 1898 for services under the influence of the Oxford Movement and St Clement's
column4: one of the first churches to be designed by John Dando Sedding
column5: built in Boscombe in 1871. To serve a rapidly expanding population a third church was built in the town centre in 1891. St Augustin's church was commissioned by Henry Twells who was 'priest-in-charge' there until 1900. The largest church in the town is the Richmond Hill St Andrew's Church
column6: part of the United Reformed Church. Built in 1865 and enlarged in 1891
column7: it has a seating capacity of 1
column8: 100 and is unusually ornate for a non-conformist church.

column1: Few purpose-built places of worship exist in the borough for faiths other than Christianity
column2: although with a higher proportion of Jewish residents than the national average
column3: there are three synagogues.Chabad-Lubavitch of Bournemouth is a branch of the worldwide movement. The Bournemouth Reform Synagogue
column4: formerly known as Bournemouth New Synagogue
column5: is a Reform Jewish synagogue with over 700 members. There is also the architecturally notable Bournemouth Hebrew Congregation synagogue built in 1911 with an Art Nouveau take on the Moorish Revival style. There are also two Christadelphian meeting halls in the town.The Bournemouth Islamic Centre provides information
column6: support and a place of worship for the Islamic community. There is also a mosque in the town.

column1: The word 'Bournemouth' is often used loosely to describe the South East Dorset conurbation
column2: which also contains the neighbouring towns of Poole
column3: Christchurch
column4: Wimborne Minster
column5: and Verwood. As a result
column6: "Bournemouth" is used in the following terms:

column1: Bournemouth Airport is located near Hurn in the borough of Christchurch
column2: and was originally named RAF Hurn.

column1: Bournemouth Bay is sometimes used for Poole Bay
The Bournemouth Symphony Orchestra is now based in Poole.
A number of famous people came from Bournemouth. Tony Hancock  lived for most of his early life in hotels in Bournemouth run by his parents.
A number of TV actors came from Bournemouth
column2: including
column3: Juliette Kaplan  from the BBC comedy Last of the Summer Wine
column4: Ray Lonnen  from the series The Sandbaggers (1978–80)
column5: Alison Newman
column6: actress who played Hazel Bailey  in Footballers' Wives and DI Samantha Keeble  in EastEnders. Jack Donnelly (born 1985) actor
column7: played the role of Jason  in the BBC series Atlantis and Sophie Rundle (born 1988) actress
column8: portrayed Ada Shelby  in the BBC One series Peaky Blinders and Ben Hardy (born 1991) actor
column9: played Peter Beale  in the BBC soap opera EastEnders.

column1: Authors Radclyffe Hall (1880–1943)  poet and author
column2: who wrote The Well of Loneliness a groundbreaking work in lesbian literature came from Bournemouth and Dilys Powell CBE (1901–1995)  journalist
column3: film critic of The Sunday Times for over fifty years went to school there. Patrick Ensor (1946–2007)  editor of Guardian Weekly from 1993 to 2007 also came from Bournemouth.

column1: Bournemouth has been home to a number of musicians
column2: including Max Bygraves OBE (1922–2012)  comedian
column3: singer
column4: actor and variety performer. The composer Sir Hubert Parry (1848-1918) was born in Bournemouth. One of Britain's most prolific composers of choral music he is probably best known for his setting to William Blake's words of Jerusalem. The rock band King Crimson included many musicians from Bournemouth  including brothers Michael Giles (drums) and Peter Giles (bass).

column1: Bournemouth has been the home of sporting world champions: Freddie Mills (1919–1965)
column2: who won the World Light Heavyweight title in 1948. Another famous sportsman
column3: the athlete Charles Bennett (1870–1948)
column4: lived in the town after he retired. Bennett
column5: was the first British track and field athlete to become Olympic Champion
column6: winning two gold medals and a silver at the Paris Games in 1900. The tennis player and Wimbledon Championships winner Virginia Wade OBE was born in Bournemouth.Three recipients of the Victoria Cross came from Bournemouth. Frederick Charles Riggs VC MM (1888–1918)
column7: Cecil Noble VC (1891–1915)
column8: and Lieutenant Colonel Derek Anthony Seagrim VC (1903–1943)
column9: Three flying aces came from Bournemouth too
column10: Captain Keith Muspratt MC (1897–1918)
column12: and Flight Lieutenant Charles John Sims DFC (1899–1929).And a distinguished resident of Bournemouth was Sir Donald Coleman Bailey
column13: OBE (1901–1985) a civil engineer who invented the Bailey bridge. Bailey was knighted in 1946 for his bridge design when he was living quietly in Southbourne in Bournemouth.
